target¶

class target.FixationTargetApp[source]¶

This class represents the entire application. All Target objects are properties of this class. Also, this class owns all OpenGL objects, so it’s responsible for making sure a context exists for drawing them, etc. This is also the only class knowing anything about visual angle. When it instructs targets to draw themselves, it does so in screen units, not visual angle units.

class target.Converter(window)[source]¶

Converts visual angles to screen pixels.

class target.MiniConverter[source]¶

Converts visual angles to screen pixels, without keeping track of screen offsets; useful for Component objects that need to know how to scale themselves using visual angle units but don’t know anything about the window.

class target.RetinalLocation(converter)[source]¶

Keeps track of location of target, performs conversions between visual angle and screen pixels.

class target.Console(right=1920, bufferLength=20, width=800)[source]¶

A pseudo-console to be drawn on the target window for debugging.

class target.Keys(console, logger)[source]¶

Generates key bindings and associated help messages.

class target.Logger(loc)[source]¶

Logs the position of fixation target at intervals specified by config.LOGGING_PERIOD.

class target.Target[source]¶

Superclass for target objects. Each target consists of one or more components, which can be added upon instantiation using the constructor’s COMPONENTS parameter, or added sequentially using the ADD method.

class target.Component(lineWidthDeg, radiusDeg, theta=0.0, color=[1.0, 1.0, 1.0])[source]¶

Superclass for target components. A component may be a line or a circle, for instance. A target shape, such as a star or a box, may be made up of many components.

draw(x, y)[source]¶

Draw this component at position x,y (pixels). Assume a gl context for drawing is available, generated by the caller.
